creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: young woman wearing black kimono with red under layer exposed; looking down towards PL; standing near branches of white wisteria; Japanese inscription at top
inscription: 法橋は浪花の人なれは(?) / 又平の水くきあと / 影とめて / なにわえにうつと / 月岡の筆 / 嘉栗 (Hōkyō of Osaka / The spirit of Matabei\'s brush / Reflected in this Naniwa-stile painting / Painted by Tsukioka / Karitsu (pseudonym for 4th generation head of the Mitsui family, Mitsui Takanori) (Transl. In file)
markings: LRC: 木田氏 {Kidashi} | 信天翁 {Shinten\'ō}
signed: LRC: 法(?)橋(?)月岡雪鼎戯画 {Hōkyō(?) Tsukioka Settei giga}
text: The Wisteria Maiden was a favorite subject of Ōtsue, folk paintings made in the town of Ōtsu. The paintings were believed to have auspicious properties; those hoping for a good match in marriage might buy a picture of the Maiden. The character later appeared in kabuki theater and was so popular that an entire play was eventually written around her. This classical depiction shows the Maiden as a beautiful young woman, or bijin, dancing with a wisteria branch over her shoulder. Settei, an Osaka artist, was famous for his delicately painted bijin and erotic imagery. The calligraphic inscription, by the Osaka kyōka poet Senkatei Karitsu (1748–1789), indicates that Settei painted the beauty in the spirit of Matabei’s brush, a reference to the legendary founder of Ōtsue and ukiyo-e.
title: Wisteria Maiden
